us_person_worldwide_filing.name: U.S. person (citizen/green-card holder) - worldwide U.S. filing
us_person_worldwide_filing.description: You are a U.S. citizen or U.S. lawful permanent resident (green-card holder). The U.S. taxes you on worldwide income each year, regardless of where you live. You generally use the foreign tax credit to relieve double taxation; foreign asset/account reporting may also apply.

us.note: Annual U.S. individual income tax return reporting worldwide income
Claim credit for income tax paid to Canada to mitigate double tax
Report specified foreign financial assets if thresholds are met (FATCA)
Report non-U.S. financial accounts if aggregate balance exceeds USD $10,000 at any time

us_person_worldwide_filing.why: U.S. persons must report worldwide income on Form 1040; Form 1116 prevents double taxation. Form 8938 and FBAR satisfy foreign asset/account disclosure when thresholds are met.

canadian_tax_resident_worldwide_filing.name: Canadian tax resident (worldwide Canadian filing)
canadian_tax_resident_worldwide_filing.description: You are a resident of Canada for tax purposes (factual or deemed). Canada taxes residents on worldwide income; foreign tax credits may be claimed for U.S. taxes paid. Foreign asset reporting may also apply.

ca.note: Annual Canadian individual income tax return reporting worldwide income
Claim federal foreign tax credit for U.S. income taxes paid
Report specified foreign property if cost amount exceeded CAD $100,000 at any time (Foreign income verification statement)

canadian_tax_resident_worldwide_filing.why: Canadian residents report worldwide income on the T1; Schedule T2209 provides federal foreign tax credit relief for U.S.-taxed income. T1135 fulfills foreign asset disclosure when thresholds are met.

us_resident_substantial_presence.name: U.S. resident by substantial presence test
us_resident_substantial_presence.description: You spent enough days physically in the U.S. this year (weighted 3-year formula) to be treated as a U.S. tax resident. You file a full U.S. resident return unless you qualify for an exception (e.g., closer connection).

us.note: Annual U.S. individual income tax return (or Form 1040-NR if claiming an exception)
Closer Connection Exception to Substantial Presence Test (if claiming nonresident exception)

us_resident_substantial_presence.why: Establishes your U.S. tax status; Form 8840 is required to claim the closer-connection exception to SPT.

snowbird_closer_connection.name: Snowbird with closer connection to Canada (Form 8840)
snowbird_closer_connection.description: You were in the U.S. enough days to otherwise meet the Substantial Presence Test but keep stronger ties to Canada and qualify to be taxed as a U.S. nonresident.

us.note: Stand-alone if no 1040-NR is required, or attached to 1040-NR if you must file

snowbird_closer_connection.why: Discloses the treaty/closer-connection facts so the IRS accepts nonresident status.

residency_change_dual_status.name: Residency change / dual-status year
residency_change_dual_status.description: You became or ceased to be a U.S. resident mid-year (or vice-versa for Canada). This triggers departure tax rules in Canada and dual-status filing in the U.S.

us.note: Dual-status statement attached
Treaty-based return position disclosure
For nonresident portion of year

ca.note: With emigration/immigration disclosure
List of properties by an emigrant
Capital gains/losses (for departure tax)

residency_change_dual_status.why: Both countries tax differently based on residency status; departure from Canada may trigger deemed disposition tax.

treaty_based_position.name: Treaty-based position disclosure (Form 8833 likely required)
treaty_based_position.description: You are claiming a treaty-based position that overrides or modifies U.S. tax law (e.g., Article IV tie-breaker, Article XV short-stay wage exemption, or closer-connection claim).

us.note: Treaty-Based Return Position Disclosure (required for most treaty positions)

treaty_based_position.why: The IRS requires disclosure when you take a position based on a tax treaty that reduces U.S. tax.

wages_taxable_us_source.name: Wages taxable in the United States based on U.S. workdays (source-country wages)
wages_taxable_us_source.description: You performed work while physically present in the United States. Those wages are generally U.S.-source income subject to U.S. taxation.

us.note: Report U.S.-source wages
Foreign tax credit if also taxed by Canada (for U.S. persons/residents)

ca.note: Report employment income
Foreign tax credit for U.S. taxes paid

wages_taxable_us_source.why: Source-country taxation applies to wages earned while physically present in that country.

wages_taxable_canada_source.name: Wages taxable in Canada based on Canadian workdays (source-country wages)
wages_taxable_canada_source.description: You performed work while physically present in Canada. Those wages are generally Canadian-source income subject to Canadian taxation.

ca.note: Report Canadian employment income
Foreign tax credit if also taxed by U.S.

us.note: Report worldwide income (if U.S. person)
Foreign tax credit for Canadian taxes paid

wages_taxable_canada_source.why: Source-country taxation applies to wages earned while physically present in that country.

short_stay_treaty_exemption_us.name: Short-stay treaty exemption for wages (United States)
short_stay_treaty_exemption_us.description: You qualify for the treaty short-stay exemption under Article XV (≤183 days, non-U.S. employer, not borne by U.S. PE). U.S. wages may be exempt from U.S. taxation.

us.note: Treaty-based return position disclosure
Claim exemption from withholding with employer

short_stay_treaty_exemption_us.why: Treaty exemption must be disclosed to IRS; withholding exemption claimed with employer.

short_stay_treaty_exemption_canada.name: Short-stay treaty exemption for wages (Canada)
short_stay_treaty_exemption_canada.description: You qualify for the treaty short-stay exemption under Article XV (≤183 days, non-Canadian employer, not borne by Canadian PE). Canadian wages may be exempt from Canadian taxation.

ca.note: Request for waiver of Canadian tax withholding

short_stay_treaty_exemption_canada.why: Treaty exemption allows you to request waiver of Canadian withholding on wages.

remote_work_canada_for_us_employer.name: Remote work performed in Canada for U.S. employer (sourcing & FTC coordination)
remote_work_canada_for_us_employer.description: You work remotely from Canada for a U.S. employer. Canada sources and taxes this income; U.S. may also tax depending on your status.

ca.note: Report employment income
Foreign tax credit (if applicable)

us.note: Report income (if U.S. person)
Foreign tax credit for Canadian taxes paid

remote_work_canada_for_us_employer.why: Remote work is typically sourced where services are performed (Canada), requiring FTC coordination.

remote_work_us_for_canada_employer.name: Remote work performed in the United States for Canadian employer (sourcing & FTC coordination)
remote_work_us_for_canada_employer.description: You work remotely from the U.S. for a Canadian employer. U.S. sources and taxes this income; Canada may also tax depending on your status.

us.note: Report employment income
Foreign tax credit (if applicable)

ca.note: Report income (if Canadian resident)
Foreign tax credit for U.S. taxes paid

remote_work_us_for_canada_employer.why: Remote work is typically sourced where services are performed (U.S.), requiring FTC coordination.

state_convenience_employer_exposure.name: State convenience-of-employer exposure
state_convenience_employer_exposure.description: Certain U.S. states (NY, CT, DE, NE, PA, AR) tax wages based on where your employer is located, not where you work. This can create exposure even if you're working remotely from another state or Canada.

us.note: For the convenience-of-employer state (e.g., NY IT-201)

state_convenience_employer_exposure.why: These states have non-conforming rules that may override federal treaty protections.

state_nonconformity_treaty_ftc.name: State nonconformity with treaty/FTC
state_nonconformity_treaty_ftc.description: Your U.S. state income tax return may not follow federal treaty rules or foreign tax credit calculations, creating additional state tax liability.

us.note: Check state-specific FTC and treaty conformity rules

state_nonconformity_treaty_ftc.why: States are not bound by federal tax treaties and have their own FTC rules.

social_security_totalization.name: Social security Totalization & certificate of coverage
social_security_totalization.description: The U.S.-Canada Totalization Agreement prevents double social security taxation. You need a certificate of coverage to prove which country's system covers you.

us.note: Application for certificate of coverage (U.S. coverage)

ca.note: Request from Service Canada

social_security_totalization.why: Certificate prevents double payment of CPP/EI and FICA taxes.

canadian_resident_us_rental.name: Canadian resident owning U.S. rental property
canadian_resident_us_rental.description: As a Canadian resident, you own rental property in the United States. This creates U.S. tax filing obligations and potential withholding requirements on rental income.

us.note: U.S. nonresident income tax return reporting rental income
Certificate of foreign person's claim that income is effectively connected with U.S. trade or business (to avoid 30% withholding)
State income tax return where property is located

ca.note: Report worldwide income including U.S. rental income
Claim foreign tax credit for U.S. taxes paid on rental income
Statement of real estate rentals

canadian_resident_us_rental.why: U.S. taxes nonresidents on U.S.-source rental income; Canada taxes residents on worldwide income. Proper reporting and foreign tax credits prevent double taxation.

us_person_canadian_rental.name: U.S. person owning Canadian rental property
us_person_canadian_rental.description: As a U.S. person, you own rental property in Canada. This creates Canadian tax filing obligations and potential withholding requirements on rental income.

ca.note: Canadian income tax return reporting rental income (if required to file)
Statement of amounts paid or credited to nonresidents (for withholding purposes)
Statement of real estate rentals

us.note: Report worldwide income including Canadian rental income
Claim foreign tax credit for Canadian taxes paid on rental income
Supplemental income and loss (rental income)

us_person_canadian_rental.why: Canada taxes nonresidents on Canadian-source rental income; U.S. taxes citizens on worldwide income. Proper reporting and foreign tax credits prevent double taxation.

cross_border_principal_residence.name: Cross-border principal residence exemption
cross_border_principal_residence.description: You're claiming principal residence exemption on a home sale in either U.S. (§121 exclusion) or Canada (principal residence exemption), and need to coordinate with the other country's rules.

us.note: Report home sale and claim §121 exclusion if applicable
Sales and other dispositions of capital assets
Capital gains and losses

ca.note: Report home sale and claim principal residence exemption
Capital gains or losses
Designation of a property as a principal residence

cross_border_principal_residence.why: Both countries have principal residence exemptions, but rules differ. Proper designation and reporting ensures optimal tax treatment in both jurisdictions.

sale_us_real_property_nonresident.name: Sale of U.S. real property by nonresident (FIRPTA)
sale_us_real_property_nonresident.description: You sold U.S. real property as a nonresident. FIRPTA requires 15% withholding on gross sales price unless you obtain a withholding certificate.

us.note: Report capital gain from U.S. real property sale
U.S. withholding tax return for dispositions by foreign persons of U.S. real property interests
Application for withholding certificate for dispositions by foreign persons of U.S. real property interests
State capital gains tax return

sale_us_real_property_nonresident.why: FIRPTA (Foreign Investment in Real Property Tax Act) requires withholding and filing to ensure nonresidents pay U.S. tax on gains from U.S. real estate sales.

sale_canadian_real_property_nonresident.name: Sale of Canadian real property by nonresident (Section 116)
sale_canadian_real_property_nonresident.description: You sold Canadian real property as a nonresident. Section 116 requires clearance certificate and withholding unless you obtain proper clearance.

ca.note: Request by a non-resident of Canada for a certificate of compliance related to the disposition of taxable Canadian property
Request by a non-resident of Canada for a certificate of compliance related to the disposition of Canadian resource or timber resource property
Nonresident income tax return to report capital gain

sale_canadian_real_property_nonresident.why: Section 116 clearance ensures nonresidents pay Canadian tax on gains from Canadian property sales. Buyer withholds 25% of purchase price if no clearance certificate obtained.

local_vacancy_speculation_tax.name: Local vacancy or speculation tax (BC, Vancouver, etc.)
local_vacancy_speculation_tax.description: Your Canadian property may be subject to local vacancy taxes, speculation taxes, or empty homes taxes imposed by provincial or municipal governments.

ca.form: BC Speculation and Vacancy Tax Declaration
ca.note: Annual declaration for B.C. properties
Annual declaration for Vancouver properties
Varies by jurisdiction

local_vacancy_speculation_tax.why: Provincial and municipal governments impose these taxes to address housing affordability. Annual declarations required even if exemption applies.

underused_housing_tax_uht.name: Underused Housing Tax (UHT)
underused_housing_tax_uht.description: You own Canadian residential property that may be subject to the federal Underused Housing Tax (UHT) of 1% of property value annually.

ca.note: Underused Housing Tax Return and Election Form

underused_housing_tax_uht.why: Federal UHT applies to Canadian residential property owned by non-Canadians and certain other owners. Annual filing required even if exemption applies; penalty for late filing is $5,000 minimum.

us_investment_income_canadian_resident.name: U.S. investment income received by Canadian resident
us_investment_income_canadian_resident.description: As a Canadian resident, you receive U.S.-source dividends, interest, or royalties. These are subject to U.S. withholding and Canadian taxation with foreign tax credit relief.

us.note: Certificate of foreign status (provide to U.S. payers to claim treaty-reduced withholding rates)
Only if required (certain circumstances)

ca.note: Report all investment income
Claim foreign tax credit for U.S. withholding taxes
Information slips from Canadian financial institutions

us_investment_income_canadian_resident.why: U.S. withholds tax on U.S.-source investment income paid to nonresidents; Canada taxes residents on worldwide income. Treaty rates and foreign tax credits prevent double taxation.

canadian_investment_income_us_person.name: Canadian investment income received by U.S. person
canadian_investment_income_us_person.description: As a U.S. person, you receive Canadian-source dividends, interest, or royalties. These are subject to Canadian withholding and U.S. taxation with foreign tax credit relief.

ca.note: Declaration of eligibility for benefits under a tax treaty (provide to Canadian payers for reduced withholding)

us.note: Report all investment income
Claim foreign tax credit for Canadian withholding taxes
Interest and ordinary dividends

canadian_investment_income_us_person.why: Canada withholds tax on Canadian-source investment income paid to nonresidents; U.S. taxes citizens on worldwide income. Treaty rates and foreign tax credits prevent double taxation.

cross_border_financial_accounts.name: Cross-border financial accounts (FBAR, FATCA, T1135 reporting)
cross_border_financial_accounts.description: You hold financial accounts (bank, brokerage, retirement, crypto) in the other country, triggering disclosure requirements FBAR, Form 8938, and/or T1135.

us.note: If non-U.S. accounts exceed $10,000 at any time
If foreign financial assets exceed thresholds

ca.note: If foreign property cost exceeds CAD $100,000 at any time

cross_border_financial_accounts.why: Both countries require disclosure of foreign financial accounts to ensure worldwide income reporting and combat tax evasion.

pfic_reporting_canadian_funds.name: PFIC reporting for Canadian mutual funds and ETFs (Form 8621)
pfic_reporting_canadian_funds.description: As a U.S. person, you hold Canadian mutual funds, ETFs, or other non-U.S. pooled investment funds that are classified as Passive Foreign Investment Companies (PFICs), requiring complex annual reporting.

us.note: Information return by a shareholder of a passive foreign investment company (required for EACH PFIC)
Report PFIC income or gains

pfic_reporting_canadian_funds.why: U.S. tax law treats PFICs punitively to discourage offshore investing. Complex reporting and unfavorable tax treatment (interest charge, no capital gains rates) unless QEF or mark-to-market election made.

withholding_documentation_maintenance.name: Withholding documentation maintenance (W-8BEN, W-9, NR forms)
withholding_documentation_maintenance.description: You need to furnish or update withholding certificates with payers in both countries to claim treaty benefits or avoid incorrect withholding.

us.note: For nonresidents receiving U.S.-source income (claim treaty benefits)
For U.S. persons receiving payments (provide TIN to payers)

ca.note: Declaration of eligibility for treaty benefits
Regulation 105 waiver application

withholding_documentation_maintenance.why: Proper withholding documentation ensures correct withholding rates and avoids over-withholding or penalties. Forms typically expire after 3 years.

cross_border_retirement_plans.name: Cross-border retirement plans (RRSP, RRIF, 401(k), IRA)
cross_border_retirement_plans.description: You hold or contribute to retirement accounts in both countries, requiring coordination of reporting, withholding, and tax treatment under treaty provisions.

us.note: U.S. information return for beneficiaries of certain Canadian registered retirement plans (discontinued, now Form 8938)
Report RRSP/RRIF if thresholds met
Report distributions if not properly deferred under treaty

ca.note: Report distributions
Foreign tax credit for U.S. withholding
Election to defer taxation under Article XVIII

cross_border_retirement_plans.why: Treaty provisions allow deferral of taxation on retirement accounts, but proper elections and reporting required. Distributions subject to withholding and coordination.

cross_border_social_benefits.name: Cross-border social benefits (CPP/OAS, U.S. Social Security)
cross_border_social_benefits.description: You receive social security or pension benefits from one country while residing in or being a tax resident of the other country.

us.note: Report CPP/OAS as foreign pension income
Treaty position if claiming exemption for OAS

ca.note: Report U.S. Social Security benefits (85% taxable in Canada under treaty)
Foreign tax credit if U.S. withheld taxes

cross_border_social_benefits.why: Treaty determines which country can tax social benefits and at what rate. CPP/OAS generally taxable in both countries; U.S. Social Security 85% taxable in Canada; proper reporting and credits prevent double taxation.

tfsa_resp_us_person.name: TFSA or RESP held by U.S. person
tfsa_resp_us_person.description: As a U.S. person, you hold a Tax-Free Savings Account (TFSA) or Registered Education Savings Plan (RESP). These are NOT recognized as tax-advantaged by the U.S., creating annual reporting and taxation requirements.

us.note: Annual return to report transactions with foreign trust (TFSA/RESP treated as foreign grantor trust)
Annual information return of foreign trust with U.S. owner
Report all income from TFSA/RESP annually (no tax-free treatment)

ca.note: TFSA/RESP contributions and withdrawals (tax-free in Canada)

tfsa_resp_us_person.why: U.S. does not recognize TFSA/RESP as qualified retirement plans under the treaty. All income is taxable annually to U.S. person, and complex trust reporting required. Severe penalties for non-filing.

cross_border_pension_transfers.name: Cross-border pension transfers or rollovers
cross_border_pension_transfers.description: You plan to transfer or roll over retirement funds between U.S. and Canadian retirement accounts (e.g., 401(k) to RRSP, or vice versa).

us.note: Report distribution and rollover
IRA contribution information
RRSP election (if applicable)

ca.note: Report transfer
Information slip for RRSP/RRIF
Employee contributions to a Canadian or U.S. retirement plan

cross_border_pension_transfers.why: Direct transfers between U.S. and Canadian retirement accounts generally not permitted without tax consequences. Proper planning required to minimize withholding and taxes.

equity_compensation_cross_border_workday.name: Equity compensation with cross-border workdays
equity_compensation_cross_border_workday.description: Your stock options, RSUs, or ESPP have grant, vest, exercise, or sale periods that span time working in both U.S. and Canada, requiring complex sourcing allocation.

us.note: Report equity compensation income
Exercise of incentive stock option (ISO)
Transfer of stock acquired through ESPP
Alternative minimum tax (if ISOs)

ca.note: Report equity compensation income
If holding foreign shares exceeds threshold
Capital gains on sale

equity_compensation_cross_border_workday.why: Equity compensation is sourced based on workdays in each country during vesting/earning period. Complex allocation formulas required to determine each country's taxing rights and prevent double taxation.

detailed_option_espp_iso_allocation.name: Detailed option/ESPP/ISO allocation and AMT analysis
detailed_option_espp_iso_allocation.description: You hold incentive stock options (ISOs), non-qualified stock options (NQSOs), or participate in ESPP requiring detailed cross-border sourcing and potential AMT analysis.

us.note: Alternative minimum tax (ISOs trigger AMT)
ISO exercise
ESPP transfer
Report compensation and capital gains

ca.note: Report employment benefit and capital gains
Report foreign shares if threshold met
Capital gains on sale

detailed_option_espp_iso_allocation.why: ISOs trigger AMT in U.S.; cross-border moves complicate sourcing; ESPP has special holding period rules. Detailed day-by-day allocation may be required for accuracy and tax treaty application.

us_estate_tax_exposure_nonresident.name: U.S. estate tax exposure for nonresident
us_estate_tax_exposure_nonresident.description: As a nonresident of the U.S., you own U.S.-situs assets (U.S. real estate, U.S. company stock, certain U.S. financial assets) that could face U.S. estate tax upon death, with only $60,000 exemption.

us.note: U.S. estate tax return for nonresident aliens
Claim treaty benefits for higher exemption under Article XXIX B

us_estate_tax_exposure_nonresident.why: U.S. imposes estate tax on U.S.-situs assets owned by nonresidents. Exemption only $60,000 (vs. $13.61M for U.S. persons). Treaty provides pro-rata unified credit based on worldwide estate.

us_gift_tax_return_requirement.name: U.S. gift tax return requirement
us_gift_tax_return_requirement.description: You made or received gifts that may require U.S. gift tax reporting. U.S. persons making large gifts, or gifting U.S.-situs assets, may need to file Form 709.

us.note: U.S. gift (and generation-skipping transfer) tax return

us_gift_tax_return_requirement.why: U.S. taxes large gifts made by U.S. persons. Gifts of U.S.-situs property by nonresidents also taxable. Annual exclusion ($18,000 in 2024) and lifetime exemption ($13.61M) apply to U.S. persons.

cross_border_trusts.name: Cross-border trusts (Forms 3520/3520-A)
cross_border_trusts.description: You create, receive distributions from, or act as trustee/beneficiary of a trust with U.S. and Canadian parties or assets, triggering complex reporting in both countries.

us.note: Annual return to report transactions with foreign trusts and receipt of certain foreign gifts
Annual information return of foreign trust with U.S. owner
Report foreign trust if thresholds met

ca.note: Trust income tax return
If foreign property exceeds threshold
Information return in respect of contributions to non-resident trusts

cross_border_trusts.why: Cross-border trusts face complex tax treatment in both countries. U.S. has severe penalties for non-reporting (35% of value for Form 3520-A). Proper planning and reporting essential.

us_shareholder_canadian_corp.name: U.S. shareholder of Canadian corporation (Forms 5471; GILTI/Subpart F)
us_shareholder_canadian_corp.description: As a U.S. person owning ≥10% of a Canadian corporation, you have extensive U.S. reporting requirements including potential GILTI (Global Intangible Low-Taxed Income) and Subpart F income inclusion.

us.note: Information return of U.S. persons with respect to certain foreign corporations
U.S. shareholder calculation of GILTI
Section 250 deduction for GILTI
Report additional income

us_shareholder_canadian_corp.why: U.S. tax law requires extensive reporting and may tax corporate earnings before distribution.

canadian_resident_us_llc.name: Canadian resident owning U.S. LLC (entity classification mismatch planning)
canadian_resident_us_llc.description: As a Canadian resident owning a U.S. LLC, there's a classification mismatch: U.S. treats it as transparent (pass-through), Canada may treat it as a corporation. This requires careful tax planning.

us.note: Report U.S.-source income (if LLC has U.S. operations)
U.S. partnership return (if multi-member LLC)

ca.note: Report income
Information return relating to controlled and not-controlled foreign affiliates
Corporate tax return (if LLC elected corporate treatment in Canada)

canadian_resident_us_llc.why: Classification mismatch can cause timing differences and potential double taxation without proper planning.

s_corp_shareholder_ineligibility.name: S-corporation shareholder ineligibility for Canadian owners (planning required)
s_corp_shareholder_ineligibility.description: Canadian residents generally cannot be shareholders of U.S. S-corporations. If you become a Canadian resident while owning S-corp shares, the election may terminate.

us.note: S-corporation return (may need to convert to C-corp)
Election to be treated as S-corporation (potential termination)

s_corp_shareholder_ineligibility.why: S-corp eligibility rules require all shareholders to be U.S. persons; Canadian residency terminates the election.

canadian_gst_hst_registration.name: Canadian GST/HST registration (place-of-supply rules)
canadian_gst_hst_registration.description: If you make taxable supplies to Canadian customers exceeding CAD $30,000, you must register for and collect GST/HST.

ca.note: GST/HST registration
Filed monthly, quarterly, or annually depending on revenue

canadian_gst_hst_registration.why: Canadian law requires businesses making taxable supplies to Canadian customers to register for GST/HST.

us_state_sales_tax_nexus.name: U.S. state sales/use tax nexus
us_state_sales_tax_nexus.description: Economic nexus rules in many U.S. states require businesses to collect and remit sales tax based on sales volume or transaction count, even without physical presence.

us.note: Varies by state
Varies by state (typically monthly or quarterly)

us_state_sales_tax_nexus.why: Post-Wayfair ruling established economic nexus for sales tax obligations.

fbar_foreign_account_reporting.name: FBAR foreign account reporting (FinCEN 114)
fbar_foreign_account_reporting.description: As a U.S. person with non-U.S. financial accounts totaling over USD $10,000 at any time during the year, you must file FBAR.

us.note: Foreign Bank Account Report (filed electronically, separate from tax return)

fbar_foreign_account_reporting.why: U.S. law requires disclosure of foreign financial accounts to combat money laundering and tax evasion.

compliance_relief_programs.name: Compliance relief programs (IRS Streamlined / CRA Voluntary Disclosures)
compliance_relief_programs.description: If you have late or missed filings, you may qualify for amnesty programs with reduced penalties.

us.note: For U.S. taxpayers residing outside the U.S.
For U.S. taxpayers residing in the U.S.
For FBAR-only issues

us.form: Delinquent International Information Return Submission Procedures
us.note: For late Forms 5471, 8938, etc.

ca.note: CRA program for voluntary disclosure of unreported income or unfiled returns

compliance_relief_programs.why: These programs allow taxpayers to come into compliance with reduced or eliminated penalties if non-compliance was non-willful.
